chunks.en: If you just want to program to solve small daily problems, then Python is quite suitable. If you want to explore a little more in the 'entering the industry' direction, then I suggest you learn JavaScript to make something with an interface and interaction, or study C++ and buy a few Arduino / ESP32 to play with.
If you really want to 'enter the industry', then give up on this idea as soon as possible...
It's best not to ask about this kind of life path here. Go to Zhihu, you can get a lot of pertinent advice, but I still want to hit you first. 1.

First of all, your education doesn't meet the standards, and you can't pass the basic resume screening. You don't even need to think about big data. I'm not being discriminatory based on education, etc. Of course, there are great programmers without degrees, but such people are one in a million, unless you're confident that's you, otherwise you should take another path.

Judging from your words, you are not firm in your idea of entering the industry, and you are even a little hesitant. I have seen people like this. I advised him to give up other ideas and devote himself wholeheartedly to studying hard. He always excuses himself by saying that he is just learning for fun, and what if he succeeds? Don't worry, he won't succeed. You have basically no foundation, no determination or belief. Not to mention writing code, you can't achieve anything in any other matter, even if you find a development position in a traditional industry company with a salary of a few thousand and also repair computers, you are just wasting the capital of your youth, and there is no improvement.
